quest_title: If \(P = \left[ \begin{array} { l l } { 1 } & {x } \\ { 0 } & { 1 } \end{array} \right] \) then \(P^n = \)
ans2_txt: \( \left[ \begin{array} { c c } { n} & { a ^ { n } } \\ { 0 } & { n } \end{array} \right] \)
ans3_txt: \( \left[ \begin{array} { c c } { n} & { n a } \\ { 0 } & { n } \end{array} \right] \)
explanation_txt:
For \(n=2\) \(P^n = P^2 \).

\( P^2 = \left[ \begin{array} { l l } { 1 } & {x } \\ { 0 } & { 1 } \end{array} \right] \left[ \begin{array} { l l } { 1 } & {2x } \\ { 0 } & { 1 } \end{array} \right] \)

So, we can conclude \( P^n = \left[ \begin{array} { c c } { 1 } & { n a } \\ { 0 } & { 1 } \end{array} \right]\)

quest_title: Uniform rope of length \(\text{L}\) lies on a table. If coefficient of friction is \(\text{\(\mu\) }\), then maximum length \(\text{l}\) of this rope which can over hang from edge of table without sliding is
explanation_txt:
Let m be the mass per unit length then

lmg = m(L - l)mg

or, \(\cfrac{1}{\mu}=\cfrac{\mathrm{L}-l}{l}\)
or, \(\cfrac{1}{\mu}=\cfrac{\mathrm{L}}{l}-1\)

or, \(\cfrac{\mathrm{L}}{l}=\cfrac{\mu+1}{\mu}\)
or, \(\cfrac{l}{\mathrm{L}}=\cfrac{\mu}{\mu+1}\)

\(\therefore l=\cfrac{\mu \mathrm{L}}{\mu+1}\)

quest_title: The mass and charge of an electron are \({m}\) and \({e}\) respectively. The momentum acquired by the electrons in \({l}\) cm of wire when a current \({i}\) starts to flow is
explanation_txt:
If \(a\) be the area of cross-section of wire, then its volume is \(a l .\) Let \(n\) be the number of electrons per unit volume. Now, the number of electrons in the wire is nal. The mass of electron is \(m\) and if its drift velocity be \(V_{d}\), then momentum acquired by the electrons is the momentum acquired by the electrons is the momentum acquired by wire.

\(p = nal\,m\,v_d\)

but \(v_d = \cfrac{i}{nea} \)

So, \(p = nal \, m \cfrac{i}{nea} \)

\( \therefore \, p = \cfrac{mil}{e}\)

quest_title: The points \(\left( \cfrac { a } { \sqrt { 3 } } , a \right), \left( \cfrac { 2 a } { \sqrt { 3 } } , 2 a \right), \left( \cfrac { a } { \sqrt { 3 } } , 3 a \right)\) are the vertices of
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array} { l } { \text { Let } A \left( \cfrac { a } { \sqrt { 3 } } , a \right) , B \left( \cfrac { 2 a } { \sqrt { 3 } } , 2 a \right) \text { and } C \left( \cfrac { a } { \sqrt { 3 } } , 3 a \right) } \\ { \text { Then } A B ^ { 2 } = \left( \cfrac { a } { \sqrt { 3 } } - \cfrac { 2 a } { \sqrt { 3 } } \right) ^ { 2 } + ( a - 2 a ) ^ { 2 } = \cfrac { a ^ { 2 } } { 3 } + a ^ { 2 } = \cfrac { 4 a ^ { 2 } } { 3 } } \\ { \text { Similarly } B C ^ { 2 } = \cfrac { 4 a ^ { 2 } } { 3 } \text { and } A C ^ { 2 } = 4 a ^ { 2 } } \end{array}\)

Since AB = BC. the triangle is isosceles.
question_plain_title: The points are the vertices of
explanation_plain_text: Since AB = BC. the triangle is isosceles.

quest_title: If \( \omega \) is a cube root of unity, then \(\left( 1 + \omega - \omega ^ { 2 } \right) \left( 1 - \omega + \omega ^ { 2 } \right) = \)
explanation_txt:
We have \( 1 + \omega = - \omega^2 \) and \( 1 + \omega^2 = -\omega \).

So, \( \left( 1 + \omega - \omega ^ { 2 } \right) \left( 1 - \omega + \omega ^ { 2 } \right) = ( -2 \omega^2) ( -2 \omega) = 4 \omega^3 = 4 \)

quest_title: Which of the following is not true
ans2_txt: If derivative of a function is zero at all points, then the function is constant
ans3_txt: If a function has maximum or minimum at a point, then the function is differentiable at that point and its derivative is zero
ans4_txt: If a function is constant, then its derivative is zero at all points.
explanation_txt: It is fundamental concept; the maximum or minimum may occur at points of non-zero derivative or even at the points where derivative doesn't exist.
question_plain_title: Which of the following is not true
explanation_plain_text: It is fundamental concept; the maximum or minimum may occur at points of non-zero derivative or even at the points where derivative doesn't exist.
ans2_plain_text: If derivative of a function is zero at all points, then the function is constant
ans3_plain_text: If a function has maximum or minimum at a point, then the function is differentiable at that point and its derivative is zero
ans4_plain_text: If a function is constant, then its derivative is zero at all points.

quest_title: The random error in the arithmetic mean of 100 observations is x; then random error in the arithmetic mean of 400 observations would be
explanation_txt:
Random error is caused by inherently unpredictable fluctuations in the readings of a measurement apparatus or in the experimenter's interpretation of the instrumental reading.

Example of Random Error

One can measure length of a rod using the same micrometer multiple times and get slightly different values like 5.236 cm, 5.244 cm and 5.240 cm.

This can be reduced by taking average of multiple measurements.

Increasing the number of observations of the same quantity by \(n\) times, reduces the random error in mean value by \(\cfrac{1}{n}\) times.
question_plain_title: The random error in the arithmetic mean of 100 observations is x; then random error in the arithmetic mean of 400 observations would be
explanation_plain_text:
Random error is caused by inherently unpredictable fluctuations in the readings of a measurement apparatus or in the experimenter's interpretation of the instrumental reading.

Example of Random Error

One can measure length of a rod using the same micrometer multiple times and get slightly different values like 5.236 cm, 5.244 cm and 5.240 cm.

This can be reduced by taking average of multiple measurements.

Increasing the number of observations of the same quantity by times, reduces the random error in mean value by times.

quest_title: F\({}_{1}\) + F\({}_{2}\) = 16 N and \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}_{1}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}_{2}}\) = 8 N and \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}_{1}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}_{2}}\) is perpendicular to smaller force then individual forces are
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{F}_{1}+\mathrm{F}_{2}=16 \mathrm{N} \text { . }} \\ {\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}_{1}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}_{2}}=8=\overrightarrow{\mathrm{R}}} \\ {\operatorname{Tan} 90^{\circ}=\cfrac{\mathrm{F}_{2} \sin \theta}{\mathrm{F}_{1}+\mathrm{F}_{2} \cos \theta}} \\ {\text { Or, } \cfrac{1}{0}=\cfrac{\mathrm{F}_{2} \sin \theta}{\mathrm{F}_{1}+\mathrm{F}_{2} \cos \theta}} \\ {\text { Or, } \mathrm{F}_{1}+\mathrm{F}_{2} \cos \theta=0}\end{array}\)

\(\begin{array}{l}{\text { Or, } \cos \theta=-\cfrac{\mathrm{F}_{1}}{\mathrm{F}_{2}}, \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \text { (ii) }} \\ {\mathrm{R}=\sqrt{\mathrm{F}_{1}^{2}+2 \mathrm{F}_{1} \mathrm{F}_{2} \cos \theta+\mathrm{F}_{2}^{2}}} \\ {\text { Or, } 8^{2}=\mathrm{F}_{1}^{2}+\mathrm{F}_{2} \cos \theta+\mathrm{F}_{2}^{2}} \\ {\text { Or, } 8^{2}=\mathrm{F}_{2}^{2}-\mathrm{F}_{1}^{2}} \\ {\text { Or, } \mathrm{F}_{2}-\mathrm{F}_{1}=\cfrac{64}{\mathrm{F}_{1}+\mathrm{F}_{2}}=\ldots \ldots \ldots \text { (iii) }} \\ {\text { Or, } \mathrm{F}_{2}-\mathrm{F}_{1}=4 \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \text { (iii) }} \\ {\text { Or, } \mathrm{F}_{2}-\mathrm{F}_{1}=4 \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \text { (iii) }} \\ {\text { Adding (i) } 8 \mathrm{x} \text { (iii) }} \\ {2 \mathrm{F}_{2}=20} \\ {\mathrm{F}_{2}=10 \mathrm{N} \& \mathrm{F}_{1}=6 \mathrm{N}}\end{array}\)
question_plain_title: F + F = 16 N and = 8 N and is perpendicular to smaller force then individual forces are

quest_title: A particle is constrained to move on a straight-line path. It returns to the starting point after 10 sec. The total distance covered by the particle during this time is 30 m. Which of the following statements about the motion of the particle is false?
explanation_txt:
Displacement of the particle will be zero because it comes back to its starting point

Average speed \(= \cfrac { \text { Total distance } } { \text { Total time } } = \cfrac { 30 m } { 10 \text { sec } } = 3 m / s\)

\(\therefore\) The incorrect one is option C.
question_plain_title: A particle is constrained to move on a straight-line path. It returns to the starting point after 10 sec. The total distance covered by the particle during this time is 30 m. Which of the following statements about the motion of the particle is false?
explanation_plain_text:
Displacement of the particle will be zero because it comes back to its starting point

Average speed

The incorrect one is option C.

quest_title: A train of mass 2 \(\times\) 10\({}^{5}\) kg moves at a constant speed of 72 km/hr up a straight incline against a frictional force of 1.28 \(\times\) 10\({}^{4}\) N. The incline is such that train rises 1 m for every 100 m then rate of increase in PE is
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{P E}{t}=\cfrac{m g h}{t}=\cfrac{m g s \sin \theta}{t}\)

\(\qquad=m g v \sin \theta\)
\(\qquad=2 \times 10^{5} \times 10 \times 20 \times \cfrac{1}{100}\)
\(\qquad=4 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{W}\)

quest_title: A ring rolls down an inclined plane. The fraction of total energy that is associated with rotational motion is
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{\mathrm{KE}_{\mathrm{rot}}}{\mathrm{KE}}=\cfrac{\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{I} \omega^{2}}{\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{m} v^{2}+\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{I} \omega^{2}}\)

\(\qquad=\cfrac{\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{mR}^{2} \cdot \cfrac{\mathrm{v}^{2}}{\mathrm{R}^{2}}}{\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{m} v^{2}+\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{mR}^{2} \cfrac{v^{2}}{\mathrm{R}^{2}}}=\cfrac{1}{2}\)

quest_title: Boltzmann's constant (K) is 1.36\(\times\)10\({}^{-23}\)J/K then KE of a molecule of hydrogen gas at 527\({}^{0}\)c is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{KE} &=\cfrac{3}{2} \mathrm{KT} \\ &=\cfrac{3}{2} \times 1.36 \times 10^{-23} \times 800 \mathrm{J} \\ &=1.6 \times 10^{-20} \mathrm{J} \end{aligned}\)
question_plain_title: Boltzmann's constant (K) is 1.3610J/K then KE of a molecule of hydrogen gas at 527c is

ans2_plain_text: 1.63210J
ans3_plain_text: 1.07510J
ans4_plain_text: 0.72510J

quest_title: For a coil having \(\text{L}\) = 2 mH, current flows through it is \(\text{i}\) = \(\text{t}\)\({}^{2}\)\(\text{e}\)\({}^{-}\)\(\text{\({}^{t}\)}\), then the time at which emf becomes zero is
explanation_txt:
\(E=L \cfrac{d i}{d t}=2 \times 10^{-3} \times \cfrac{d}{d t}\left(t^{2} e^{-1}\right) \)
\(E=L \cfrac{d i}{d t}=2 \times 10^{-3}\left(2 t e^{t}-e^{t} \cdot t^{2}\right) \)
\(\therefore E=0 ; \Rightarrow \cfrac{\left(2 t-t^{2}\right)}{e t}=0 \quad \therefore t=2 \mathrm{sec} \)

quest_title: Two short bar magnets of magnetic moments \(\text{M}\) each are arranged at the opposite corners of a square of side \(\text{d}\) such that their centres coincide with the corners and their axes are parallel. If the like poles are in the same direction, the magnetic induction at any of the other corners of the square is
explanation_txt:
ABCD is square of side ‘d’. Two bars magnets are arranged at the opposite corners B and D of square. Consider at ‘A’ of square.

The magnetic induction of A due to magnet \(H_1\).

\(B_{0}=\cfrac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \cdot \cfrac{2 M}{d^{3}}\) along \(\mathrm{BA}\)
Similarly, the magnetic induction at A due to magnet \(M_{2}\).
\(B_{e}=\cfrac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \cdot \cfrac{M}{d^{3}} \text { along } \mathrm{AB}\)
Resultant \(B=B_{a}-B_{e}=\cfrac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \cdot \cfrac{M}{d^{3}}\)

explanation_plain_text:
ABCD is square of side ‘d’. Two bars magnets are arranged at the opposite corners B and D of square. Consider at ‘A’ of square.

The magnetic induction of A due to magnet .

along

quest_title: \[ 1+\cfrac{a-b}{a} +\cfrac{1}{2\, !} \left(\cfrac{a-b}{a} \right)^{2} +\cfrac{1}{3\, !} \left(\cfrac{a-b}{a} \right)^{3} +......\infty =\]
explanation_txt:
\(1+\cfrac{a-b}{a} +\cfrac{1}{2\; !} \left(\cfrac{a-b}{a} \right)^{2} \; +\cfrac{1}{3\; !} \left(\cfrac{a-b}{a} \right)^{3} +........\) \[=1+\cfrac{\left(\cfrac{a-b}{a} \right)}{1\; !} +\cfrac{\left(\cfrac{a-b}{a} \right)^{2} }{2\; !} +\cfrac{\left(\cfrac{a-b}{a} \right)^{3} }{3\; !} +.......\]

\(=e^{(a-b)/a} =e^{1-(b/a)} =e^{1} .e^{-b/a} =\cfrac{e}{e^{b/a} } .\)

quest_title: The general solution of \(\sin x + \cos x + \sec x + \text{cosec}x = 0\) is
explanation_txt: \(\sin x + \cos x + \sec x + \text{cosec}x = 0 \\ \Rightarrow \sin x + \cos x + \cfrac{1}{\cos x} + \cfrac{1}{\sin x} = 0 \\ \Rightarrow \sin^2 x \cos x + \cos^2 x \sin x + \sin x + \cos x = 0 \\ \Rightarrow (\sin x \cos x +1)(\sin x +\cos x) = 0 \\ \Rightarrow \sin 2x = -2 \quad (\text{discarded}) \\ \text{Or,} \\ \sin x + \cos x = 0 \\ \Rightarrow \tan x = -1 \\ \Rightarrow x = n \pi - \cfrac{\pi}{4} \)

quest_title: 100ml of 0.2M \(\text{H\({}_{2}\)SO\({}_{4}\)}\) is added to 100ml of 0.2M NaOH. The resulting solution will be
explanation_txt:
100 ml of 0.2M \(H_2SO_4\) = 20 ml of 1M \(H_2SO_4\) = 40 ml of 1N \(H_2SO_4\)

100 ml of 0.2M NaOH = 20 ml of 1M NaOH = 20 ml of 1N NaOH

Since, acid content is higher, the resulting solution is acidic.
question_plain_title: 100ml of 0.2M is added to 100ml of 0.2M NaOH. The resulting solution will be
explanation_plain_text:
100 ml of 0.2M = 20 ml of 1M = 40 ml of 1N

100 ml of 0.2M NaOH = 20 ml of 1M NaOH = 20 ml of 1N NaOH

Since, acid content is higher, the resulting solution is acidic.

quest_title: If \(\omega \) is a complex cube root of unity, then for positive integral value of \(n\), the product of \(\omega . \omega ^ { 2 } \cdot \omega ^ { 3 } \ldots \ldots \ldots \omega ^ { n }\), will be
explanation_txt:
\( \omega . \omega ^ { 2 } \cdot \omega ^ { 3 } \ldots \ldots \ldots \omega ^ { n } = \omega ^ { 1 + 2 + 3 + \ldots \ldots + n }= \omega ^ { n ( n + 1 ) / 2 } \)

On putting \(n = 1,2,3 , \dots . .\) we get

\(= \omega ^ { 1 ( 1 + 1 ) / 2 } = \omega , \omega ^ { 2 ( 2 + 1 ) / 2 } = \omega ^ { 3 } = 1 , \ldots . . \omega ^ { 4 ( 5 ) / 2 } = \omega ^ { 10 } = \omega\)

So, the product gives either 1 or \( \omega \).

explanation_plain_text:
On putting we get

So, the product gives either 1 or .
